xi:fallback.para: Concatenate a list of strings.
Map a function over a list and concatenate the resulting strings.
Like `concatMapStrings` except that the f functions also gets the position as a parameter.
Place an element between each element of a list
Concatenate a list of strings with a separator between each element
Maps a function over a list of strings and then concatenates the result with the specified separator interspersed between elements.

listitem.para: Function to map over the list

xi:fallback.para: Same as `concatMapStringsSep`, but the mapping function additionally receives the position of its argument.

listitem.para: Function that receives elements and their positions

xi:fallback.para: Construct a Unix-style, colon-separated search path consisting of the given `subDir` appended to each of the given paths.

Construct a Unix-style search path by appending the given `subDir` to the specified `output` of each of the packages. If no output by the given name is found, fallback to `.out` and then to the default.
Construct a library search path (such as RPATH) containing the libraries for a set of packages

example.title: lib.strings.makeLibraryPath usage example
example.programlisting: makeLibraryPath [ "/usr" "/usr/local" ] => "/usr/lib:/usr/local/lib" pkgs = import <nixpkgs> { } makeLibraryPath [ pkgs.openssl pkgs.zlib ] => "/nix/store/9rz8gxhzf8sw4kf2j2f1grr49w8zx5vj-openssl-1.0.1r/lib:/nix/store/wwh7mhwh269sfjkm6k5665b5kgp7jrk2-zlib-1.2.8/lib"

xi:fallback.para: Construct a binary search path (such as $PATH) containing the binaries for a set of packages.
Construct a perl search path (such as $PERL5LIB)
Construct a perl search path recursively including all dependencies (such as $PERL5LIB)
Depending on the boolean `cond', return either the given string or the empty string. Useful to concatenate against a bigger string.

listitem.para: String to return if condition is true

xi:fallback.para: Determine whether a string has given prefix.
Determine whether a string has given suffix.
Determine whether a string contains the given infix

example.title: lib.strings.hasInfix usage example
example.programlisting: hasInfix "bc" "abcd" => true hasInfix "ab" "abcd" => true hasInfix "cd" "abcd" => true hasInfix "foo" "abcd" => false

xi:fallback.para: Convert a string to a list of characters (i.e. singleton strings). This allows you to, e.g., map a function over each character. However, note that this will likely be horribly inefficient; Nix is not a general purpose programming language. Complex string manipulations should, if appropriate, be done in a derivation. Also note that Nix treats strings as a list of bytes and thus doesn't handle unicode.
Manipulate a string character by character and replace them by strings before concatenating the results.

listitem.para: Function to map over each individual character

example.title: lib.strings.stringAsChars usage example
example.programlisting: stringAsChars (x: if x == "a" then "i" else x) "nax" => "nix"

xi:fallback.para: Escape occurrence of the elements of `list` in `string` by prefixing it with a backslash.
Quote string to be used safely within the Bourne shell.
Quote all arguments to be safely passed to the Bourne shell.
Turn a string into a Nix expression representing that string
Converts an ASCII string to lower-case.
Converts an ASCII string to upper-case.
Appends string context from another string. This is an implementation detail of Nix.

Strings in Nix carry an invisible `context` which is a list of strings representing store paths. If the string is later used in a derivation attribute, the derivation will properly populate the inputDrvs and inputSrcs.
Cut a string with a separator and produces a list of strings which were separated by this separator.
NOTE: this function is not performant and should never be used.
Return a string without the specified prefix, if the prefix matches.

listitem.para: Prefix to remove if it matches

xi:fallback.para: Return a string without the specified suffix, if the suffix matches.

listitem.para: Suffix to remove if it matches

xi:fallback.para: Return true if string v1 denotes a version older than v2.
Return true if string v1 denotes a version equal to or newer than v2.

example.title: lib.strings.versionAtLeast usage example
example.programlisting: versionAtLeast "1.1" "1.0" => true versionAtLeast "1.1" "1.1" => true versionAtLeast "1.1" "1.2" => false

xi:fallback.para: This function takes an argument that's either a derivation or a derivation's "name" attribute and extracts the version part from that argument.
Extract name with version from URL. Ask for separator which is supposed to start extension.
Create an --{enable,disable}-<feat> string that can be passed to standard GNU Autoconf scripts.
Create an --{enable-<feat>=<value>,disable-<feat>} string that can be passed to standard GNU Autoconf scripts.
Create an --{with,without}-<feat> string that can be passed to standard GNU Autoconf scripts.
Create an --{with-<feat>=<value>,without-<feat>} string that can be passed to standard GNU Autoconf scripts.
Create a fixed width string with additional prefix to match required width.
This function will fail if the input string is longer than the requested length.
Format a number adding leading zeroes up to fixed width.
Check whether a value can be coerced to a string
Check whether a value is a store path.

example.title: lib.strings.isStorePath usage example
example.programlisting: isStorePath "/nix/store/d945ibfx9x185xf04b890y4f9g3cbb63-python-2.7.11/bin/python" => false isStorePath "/nix/store/d945ibfx9x185xf04b890y4f9g3cbb63-python-2.7.11/" => true isStorePath pkgs.python => true isStorePath [] || isStorePath 42 || isStorePath {} || â€¦ => false

xi:fallback.para: Parse a string string as an int.

example.title: lib.strings.toInt usage example
example.programlisting: toInt "1337" => 1337 toInt "-4" => -4 toInt "3.14" => error: floating point JSON numbers are not supported

xi:fallback.para: Read a list of paths from `file`, relative to the `rootPath`. Lines beginning with `#` are treated as comments and ignored. Whitespace is significant.
NOTE: This function is not performant and should be avoided.
Read the contents of a file removing the trailing \n
